node.text:
“The earth has music for those who listen.” ~ William Shakespeare 🎵

It’s #WorldListeningDay!

How would you describe the earth’s music? What simple, or profound, messages have you received from her?

We give value to the sounds we hear—whether that is through our attention and focus, or the value or perception we afford to that sound. We can also choose to give value to the sound of, by setting aside space for—silence. 

The Grand Canyon provides us an incredible opportunity to listen. We can:
💎 Listen to the brilliant sparkle of the night skies. 
💎 Listen for birds as they express their unique songs, calls, flight patterns or movements.
💎 Listen, and feel for, when the winds start to pick up in their intensity. 
💎 Listen to the gentle caress, or raging roar, of the Colorado River as it continues its timeless generosity and continuous flow. 
💎 Listen to the Canyon open up with wonder, as the golden hues of a sunset paint the horizon in an unearthly awe. 
💎 Listen as a ranger shares with us their passion for the Canyon, as we hear their voice rise with gusto and their palpable excitement. 
💎 Listen to, and learn from, the spoken (or unspoken) histories that intimately connect indigenous people through their sacred connection to this land and this place. 

Silence is not the absence of sound but the presence of one’s ability to listen. So, today, gift yourself some moments for silence. You may find that in silence, you open up to an entire world that is waiting to share in her musical splendor with you!

For additional listening and viewing opportunities from the Grand Canyon, check out our “Minute Out In It” video series, which features compelling stories (told without words) of the diverse soundscapes and landscapes throughout the park. https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/photosmultimedia/minute-out-in-it.htm

- AB

#WorldListeningDay #ListenUp #ListenIn #Soundscapes 

[#VideoDescription: Watching cloud shadows pass lazily across the layers of the canyon during the winter season.]

NPS Video/R. Lane

An audio-described version of the film can be found here: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=772643A9-9D3B-4B0E-B6DC-D90C1DEB262E

node.title: World Listening Day: Minute Out In It In the Clouds

node.text:
Our Branch Chief of Emergency Services has an important message for you!

Grand Canyon National Park is in an Excessive Heat Warning. Inner Canyon temperatures are reaching as high as 120°F (48.9°C)! 

Your body cannot cool itself or replenish its water or salt in these conditions. Please take a look at this short video addressing heat illness, heat stroke, and how best to visit Grand Canyon during these dog days of summer.

For an audio described version and captions visit: https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=A0226CAB-9569-438C-BD0C-6514B142EF28

For more information on summer hiking visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/hike-smart.htm

#RecreateResponsibly #HikeSmart

node.text:
As we get ready for Memorial Day Weekend and park visitation increases, we’d like to remind you that May is Wildland Fire Awareness Month. 

As public lands have started announcing fire restrictions in preparation for another hot and dry summer, we want to share with you a story that has become all too common. Whether you want a fire for ambience, heat, or marshmallow roasting, it is incredibly important to know if your fire is legal and safe—fires should never be started to burn waste. 

For more information and current fire restrictions visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/management/firemanagement.htm 

For closed captioned and audio described versions of this video visit: 
https://www.nps.gov/media/video/view.htm?id=813BBAB5-1F03-4702-8823-AF8D16D646FA 

#WildlandFireAwarenessMonth #FireSafety #MemorialDay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 09, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
“What you need, what we all need, is silence. Stop the noise in your mind in order for the wondrous sounds of life to be heard.” ~ Thich Nhat Hanh ☮️

On this Mindful Monday, we wanted to share a poem born out of such inspiration to listen, observe and fully receive life as it is happening in this moment. 

🌊River Flow 
I feel these rush of energies ✨
Pass through my body 
The water steadily carving out 
Her own path and way 
Nothing to stop her 
Just an endless flow 
A steady commitment to her path 
Onward! 
Downstream, relaxed in her existence 
Carrying, carving out 
Greeting her existence 
Alive and full of life 
Swirling with surprises 
Breathe in your tranquil depths 
As we welcome to us, this new day!

What moments in your life have you felt a similar sense of peace wash over you?
 
- AB

#MindfulMonday #Mindfulness #NatureAbundance #ListenIn #Appreciation 

[#ImageDescription: At sunrise, a waterfall gently flows over a bed of shadowed rocks with views of a narrow, red-colored canyon in the background. NPS Photo/A. Wilson]

node.accessibility_caption: From a calm stretch of river, a series of colorful cliffs rise to form a vast canyon landscape with fluffy summer clouds above in a deep blue sky. “Sentinels of Time” 30 by 40 inches, acrylic, ©2021, John D Cogan.

node.text:
“Sentinels of Time” by John D Cogan, 30 by 40 inches, acrylic, ©2021, 38 by 48 framed. 

"Anyone who has rafted the Colorado River knows, that when viewed from the inside out, the Grand Canyon seems almost to be a separate and distinct place. The temples, buttes and walls, once observed from the rim, rising out of the depths, now tower above, even more massive and commanding. 

Like the River, time seems to mostly drift by, each bend and turn presenting new vistas in front and behind. But there are surprises, the churning white water of rapids, the changes in geologic strata as the chasm deepens, and glimpses of inhabitants who make the Canyon their home. One thing is always constant for the artist: whether looking into it or out of it, the Grand Canyon never disappoints." — John D Cogan, Artist  @johndcogan
 
The 13th Annual Celebration of Art will take place September 11, 2021 - January 17, 2022. 

Since 2009, Celebration of Art (CoA) has invited participating artists to paint “en plein air” (outside on location) for a week at the canyon. The works produced from the event will be available for purchase online and on display at historic Kolb Studio for a four-month sale and exhibition beginning Sunday, September 19, 2021.

CoA is a wonderful tradition at Grand Canyon National Park, providing a vibrant experience for visitors, a venue for artists inspired by the canyon, and a successful fundraiser to benefit a dedicated art venue and arts programming at the park. For this year's event, we are welcoming back all of our 2020 artists, including John D Cogan. 

https://www.grandcanyon.org/events/celebration-of-art/ @grand_canyon_conservancy

node.accessibility_caption: Podcast logo: Text in red letters, "Echoes From The Canyon" above a 1960'portable radio with several knobs and an antenna. Superimposed into the top half of the radio is a profile of colorful Grand Canyon walls with a river below. Text below the graphic reads, "Grand Canyon National Park".

node.text:
Echoes from the Canyon Radio Hour presents: 

GRAND CANYON MYSTERIES

A new podcast episode featuring tall tales, disappearances, folklore, and unfathomable mysteries from Grand Canyon. 

go.nps.gov/echo 

#History #HistoryMemes #GrandCanyon #Arizona #StoryTime #StoryTelling #OralHistory #PodcastersOfInstagram #Podcast #Podcasting #NationaParks #NationalPark

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of nature and tree.

node.text:
You know, we spend a lot of time showing off the South Rim of Grand Canyon, but we are past due for a North Rim spotlight. ✨

From the rolling meadows at the entrance, to the wildflowers that hug the dense green forests, the North Rim is much more than 𝘢𝘯𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳 𝘷𝘪𝘦𝘸 𝘰𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘰𝘯. 

Many venture to the taller side (1000 feet above the South Rim) of Grand Canyon to escape the crowds, beat (though not that well this season) the heat, and to experience a more expansive and gradual view of the canyon's depths. Over a 4 hour drive from the Village on the South Rim, the North Rim is close to many park units like Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, Vermillion Cliffs National Monument and Zion National Park. 

Some may say that the North Rim is the "best rim", and whereas we don’t like to take too much stock in that assessment…we won’t say we disagree. 

-a South Rim Ranger (AR)

#FindYourPark #GrandCanyon #FridayFeeling
NPS Photos/ A. Rehkopf

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of nature and tree.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text:
#FridayFeeling

Leaping into the weekend…and our own natural beauty! 💖

“When we accept our own wild beauty, it is put into perspective, and we are no longer poignantly aware of it anymore, but neither would we forsake it or disclaim it either. Does a wolf know how beautiful she is when she leaps? Does a feline know what beautiful shapes she makes when she sits? Is a bird awed by the sound it hears when it snaps open its wings? Learning from them, we just act in our own true way and do not draw back from or hide our natural beauty. Like the creatures, we just are, and it is right.” ~ Clarissa Pinkola Estés

Grand Canyon is home to 91 species of mammals, 447 known species of birds, 48 species of reptiles, 10 species of amphibians, plus insects, spiders, and more.

To learn more about wildlife at Grand Canyon, visit: https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/nature/wildlife.htm

- AB

[#ImageDescription: A red fox (Vulpes vulpes) takes a giant leap with its focus intent on the snow-covered ground below. NPS Photo/N. Herbert, Yellowstone National Park]

[#ImageDescription: A California condor (Gymnogyps californianus), with wings spread, soars over a colorful canyon with a clear blue sky above. NPS Photo]

[#ImageDescription: A bobcat (Lynx rufus) kitten, with large eyes and ears, perched in a tree, looks at the camera. NPS Photo/E. Hope]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of animal and nature.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of nature.
Photo by GrandCanyonNPS on August 06, 2021. May be an image of big cat and nature.
A view of a colorful  canyon full of buttes and prominences, in early morning light.

node.text:
It's summertime, and the living is fairly easy...well, easier—on the rim!

If you are planning a trip to Grand Canyon at the end of this week (8/5-8/6) please be aware that we will be in an Excessive Heat Warning, meaning that temperatures will be well-above average.
Hike in the early morning or late evening—avoid hiking between 10am and 4pm. Bring a headlamp, as well as plenty of food and water, in case you need extra time to cool off in the shade. Consider hiking above the rim where the temperatures will be their coolest; if you think 90°F and above is cool!

Be safe and hike smart. 

Oh, and please don't bring pets into the canyon, they are not allowed on trails and are unable to regulate their body heat as well as their human companions. Their paws can get burned, too!
-AR

NPS Photo/Special Use Aerial Permit
[#ImageDescription: A view of a colorful  canyon full of buttes and prominences, in early morning light.]

node.accessibility_caption: An Arizona Fishhook cactus blooms with vibrant new pink flowers, located within the inner canyon.

node.text:
“I held a blue flower in my hand, probably a wild aster, wondering what its name was, and then thought that human names for natural things are superfluous. Nature herself does not name them. The important thing is to 𝓀𝓃𝑜𝓌 this flower, look at its color until the blueness becomes as real as a keynote of music. Look at the exquisite yellow flowerettes in the center, become very small with them. 𝐵𝑒 the flower, be the trees, the blowing grasses. Fly with the birds, jump with the squirrel!” 🐿– Sally Carrighar

In our case—be the native Arizona Fishhook cactus (mammillaria grahamii)—noticing its brightly bursting pink flowers, for this #WildflowerWednesday! 🌸

Sometimes, it's nice to "know" the answer. And sometimes, it's nice to just ✨feel✨. 

- AB 

NPS Photo/C. Brennan

node.accessibility_caption: A railed area overlooking an immense and colorful canyon, with a cloudy sky.

node.text:
Who would you like to stand here with?

Boasting some of the most incredible landscapes in the world, the United States has plenty of places to celebrate Great American Outdoors Day!

Today marks the one-year anniversary of the signing of the Great American Outdoors Act (GAOA), which provides huge investments in national parks, public lands and American Indian schools.

Entrance fees will be waived today (Aug. 4) at all fee-collecting public lands managed by the Department of Interior. Other fees, such as overnight camping, cabin rentals, group day use and use of special areas, remain in effect.

Everyone should have an opportunity to get out and enjoy public lands—happy #GreatAmericanOutdoorsDay!

NPS Photo/A. Rehkopf
[#ImageDescription: An overlook at the North Rim of Grand Canyon, showcasing a railed area overlooking an immense and colorful canyon, with a cloudy sky.]

node.accessibility_caption: Painting from 1912 by American Artist, Thomas Moran shows trees on the rocky edge of a vast canyon filled with colorful peaks and buttes

node.text:
Thomas Moran's paintings captured the majesty of Grand Canyon. His paintings helped inspire Congress to establish the National Park System in 1916. This Painting, from 1912, is entitled, "Grand Canyon of Arizona".

Applications are now open for the 2022 Grand Canyon Artist in Residence!  Details > https://grandcanyon.org/artist @Grand_Canyon_Conservancy

#Arizona #ArtistInResidence #GrandCanyon #Art #Artist 

[Description: "Painting from 1912 by American Artist, Thomas Moran shows trees on the rocky edge of a vast canyon filled with colorful peaks and buttes".]

node.accessibility_caption: Aerial views of a green-colored Colorado River flowing through a vast and colorful canyon.

node.text:
Welcome, Awe-Inspiring August! 

What are some ways we can connect with a feeling of awe, or a feeling of appreciation, this month?

When I first started working for the National Park Service in 2018, I learned the expression “Angry August.” Apparently, there was a seeming (or perceived) trend that visitors (and perhaps ourselves), were feeling a little more heated, an uptick in testiness, by the time August rolled around.

As a new employee, I was surprised to learn this, and at the same time, I thought August doesn’t have to be “angry” (I mean…August could be awesome, or awe-inspiring, or amazing, or astronomically-good, for instance!). Why was there only this one choice, or this one adjective, for August? Would our expectations for an Angry August lead to…<gasp>…just that?

So, as a new seasonal National Park Service employee, during the month of August, I challenged myself to instead repurpose August to be “Awe-Inspiring August.” (Since it felt like August needed a total rebranding, I went over-the-top with how I wanted to view the entire month—and Awe-Inspiring August was born!) 

I then wrote a sign for my office space: “Awe-Inspiring August.” Every morning when I came into work, I wrote down one thing that I could appreciate in that moment and found that by focusing on something positive, each and every day, I found more and more things to be grateful for. 

Maybe this idea of connecting with things we appreciate this month will resonate for you also? And if so, I invite you to share what you appreciate with us here.🌻

Happy Awe-Inspiring August! Be well. 

- AB

#MindfulMonday  #AweInspiringAugust #AwesomeAugust #Appreciation
#Reflection #Wellbeing

node.accessibility_caption: A reddish-brown Colorado River flowing deep within Grand Canyon, thick with silt. A footbridge across the river is visible in the shadows. NPS Photo/K. Hensel

node.text:
Behold, the power of water! We are in the monsoon here at Grand Canyon, a period of regular summer storms. Water is a precious resource in desert environments at Grand Canyon, and these storms play an important part in revitalizing the dry landscape and sustaining the many plants and animals that make Grand Canyon their home.

But while water has the power to sustain life, it also has immense destructive potential! During storms, rushing water can wash out trails, uproot trees, and turn rivers red with mud—as these photos taken within the past week here at Grand Canyon clearly show!

When visiting Grand Canyon, or any other National Park, be aware of the weather. If a storm is predicted, read the hourly forecast and plan your hike so that you won't be caught out in the rain when it starts. If you remember our messaging from earlier this summer, you'll know we want you to stay hydrated—but not like this!

[image: A reddish-brown Colorado River flowing deep within Grand Canyon, thick with silt. A footbridge across the river is visible in the shadows. NPS Photo/K. Hensel]

node.text:
Here’s to that #FridayFeeling! How will you connect with nature this weekend? (I’m in awe of her.)

- AB

Wilson; geometric patterning of an inner agave plant, NPS Photo/C. Brennan; flowers blooming in colors of pink and white from the crown of an Arizona Fishhook Cactus, NPS Photo/K.
